quote: Marking beam-out position.   Return transport: fourteen   minutes, forty seconds.
Your view any better, Geordi?
Not too bad, sir. A lot of   charged-particle precipitation,   but I can compensate.
Communicators are dysfunctional.
Tricorders?
Readings only valid within five   meters.
I'm not so sure of that... I'm   reading Worf as an unintelligent   life form.
Good thing we didn't bring   Data... we would've been   unscrambling his circuits for a   week...
Picking up something on the   positron scan, Commander.
Over here. Some electrically   conductive objects.
Recognize the markings, Worf?
Yessir. Romulan.
I wonder what the hell they were   doing in a Federation sector.
I'm picking up traces of ultritium   residue with my VISOR, Commander.   An explosive device must've been   used to destroy the craft after   it crashed.
Spread out... twenty five meter   radius... our window back closes   in nine minutes...
Commander...
Commander Riker...
COMMANDER RIKER... WORF... HEY   UP THERE...
Four minutes to beam-up, sir.
Where is he? Wait here...
La Forge to Riker... La Forge to   Worf...       HEY...
GEORDI...
Lieutenant Worf, maintain your   position.
Captain's log, Stardate 43349.2.   An unidentified distress signal   has led to the discovery of a   crashed Romulan vessel on the   surface of Galorndon Core, a   Federation planet.
We have recovered one survivor.   Lieutenant Commander La Forge   did not report back with the away   team and is still missing on the   surface.
Get him to Sickbay.
Secure Sickbay. Post guards in   visual contact at all times.
He's not going anywhere,   Lieutenant.
I'm sorry, Commander... There's   just no way to lock in on anything   down there...
Keep trying, Mister O'Brien.
(shakes his head,     useless)   The electrical storms are creating   thousands of ghosts...
Then beam some of the ghosts up   here... one of them may be La   Forge.       Request permission to lead another   away team...
Denied.       When we get another window in the   storms.
The crash site?
The Romulan craft's a total loss.   There's nothing there to salvage   -- unless we do it with tweezers.
No sign of others...
We could barely see two meters   in front of us down there...
It certainly is the last place   one would expect a Romulan   encroachment.       On the other hand, Galorndon Core   would provide ideal cover for an   opening move of a new offensive.
I doubt they were there for the   climate.
We thought it would be like   working on a Vulcan, but there   are subtle differences... too many   of them...
Can you treat him?
He has cell damage in vital   areas... He's going to need a   transfusion of compatible   ribosomes in order to recover.   I'm setting up a schedule to   test every member of the crew.
Will he survive?
I can't answer that yet.
Let me put it another way -- will   he survive long enough to tell   us what he was doing here?
It is an important consideration,   Doctor.
I can't put his life in any   additional jeopardy...
Nor would we ask you to.
I can bring him around for a few   minutes...
There is one serious complication.   His brainwaves indicate early   neural-pathway degeneration.
A head injury?
There was no obvious cranial   trauma. I'm guessing the exposure   to the magnetic fields on the   surface was slowly breaking down   his synaptic connections.
Will it affect Geordi the same   way?
You are aboard the Federation   Starship Enterprise.       We are treating your injuries.   How long were you on Galorndon   Core?       Do you understand me?
I will not answer questions.
We must know if there are any   other survivors on the surface.
I am alone. I will not answer   any questions.
Is there a mother ship we should   advise of your condition?
The only answer he offers is that   he was alone...
... which suggests he wasn't.
Something that can cut through   the storm... to give us some way   to signal him...
A neutrino pulse...
We could build a portable neutrino   source and send it in a probe to   the surface. It would be like   a beacon.
A neutrino pulse would send   non-charged particles back up   through the atmosphere... and   would be detectable by Geordi's   VISOR.
He'll be able to show us that he's   found it by modifying the   pulse...
Make it so.
Captain, I have a new transmission   on a parallel frequency to the   distress call...
From the planet?
No sir... from inside the Romulan   Zone. We should be able to view   the transmission.
On screen.
Tomalak to Pi.       We have received your distress   signal. Respond.       If you can hear me, we are   entering the Neutral Zone now...   We will reach you in six hours.
Mister Worf, hail the Romulan   vessel.
Frequency open, sir.
Romulan vessel. This is Captain   Jean-Luc Picard of the Federation   Starship Enterprise.
The frequency is open, sir.
Commander Tomalak, we have   intercepted your transmission.   You are not to enter Federation   space.
Captain Picard, my apologies.   If I had known you were in this   sector, I certainly would have   advised you before crossing the   Neutral Zone.
Really...
I'm sure you'll understand when   I explain. Simply, one of our   ships had a slight navigational   error and apparently crashed on   Galorndon Core.
A "slight" navigational error.   Nearly half a light year past the   Neutral Zone.
I assure you, Captain, no   aggression was intended.
Commander, we have recovered one   of your survivors.
He is on board your ship?
We are treating him for severe   injuries.
And his craft?
Destroyed... deliberately... after   the crash.
Standard procedure for all Romulan   crews.
For all Romulan crews in enemy   space... which would suggest they   knew where they were, Commander.
If I were lost and uncertain, I   would not take any chances. Nor   I suspect would you, Captain.   May I speak to him?
He is not conscious... and not   well enough to leave Sickbay.
Captain, with your permission...
I am Doctor Crusher, the medical   officer. We are doing everything   we can for him and it still may   not be enough. Any medical   guidance your ship's doctor can   offer...
My dear, there is no way to talk   you through the intricacies of   Romulan medicine. His life is in   your hands.
I assume that you are prepared   to leave at once and rendezvous   with me in the Neutral Zone.
I have an away team on the   surface. We are waiting for a   window in the storm to beam them   back.
And then you will return my   officer?
Are there any other Romulans we   should be looking to recover from   Galorndon Core... ?
No. It was a one-man craft.       Captain, we will be at the   Federation border of the Neutral   Zone in roughly five hours. We   will expect you to rendezvous at   that time.
Counselor?
There is great hostility behind   his smile, Captain. To complete   his mission, he will stop at   nothing.
Including the Neutral Zone border?
Sir, I see no reason to return   the Romulan to his ship. He   should be held and interrogated.
We do have a right to detain him,   Captain.
Without clear evidence of intent,   it would not be a simple matter.
This was obviously not pilot's   error, Captain... it requires a   response from us.
We must measure the response   carefully, Number One. Or history   may remember Galorndon Core   alongside Pearl Harbor and Station   Salem-One... as the stage for   a bloody preamble to war.
What the hell... ?
About five degrees off... huh.   The water maybe... ?
I want him off all the drugs...   they aren't doing anything...       Doctor Crusher to Picard.
Go ahead.
My patient is not responding to   treatment.
You haven't found a compatible   ribosome donor?
The lab is still processing the   tests... early results indicate   humans have far too many   biorejection factors. I've also   ruled out the Vulcans we've   tested.
We'll try a little old-fashioned   country medicine... keep the   fever down, try to let the body   heal itself...
Keep me advised. Picard out.
Captain, the neutrino beacon is   operational. We've placed it   aboard a class three probe.
Well done, Ensign.       Launch the probe.
Probe has entered the atmosphere,   sir.
The neutrino stream is coming in   strongly. Sensors are tracking   the probe despite the   interference.
This better not be another   malfunction...
A stationary neutrino source...
Wesley Crusher.
You are my prisoner.
Right. Congratulations.   Certainly, a strategic triumph   for the Romulan Empire.
Stay there.
My shoes are getting full of   sand... I just hate that, don't   you? You think we could just   maybe move outta the...
How many other Federation troops   are with you?
We just stopped by to rescue you,   big fella... which I'm still   willing to do if you'll put that   down...
Or we can just stand here and take   in the view...
Your name and rank.
Lieutenant Commander Geordi La   Forge. I don't believe I caught   yours... ?
A Romulan ship will arrive   shortly... you will accompany me   on board...

Uh, I really don't think that's   gonna happen, Ensign... or is it   Commodore...    (a beat, Bochra doesn't     react)   Yeah, see... we heard your message   too... and well, the fleet's in,   Commodore. Sky's full of   Federation ships.
You're lying.
I never lie when I've got sand   in my shoes, Commodore.
Get up.
Seriously. There's only one way   out of here. Put that down and   I'll take you back to my ship as   soon as there's a window in the   storm...
You gotta be kidding.
Sit.
Welcome to Galorndon Core, where   no good deed goes unpunished...
Yes, Doctor...
Lieutenant. Good. Come in.   Please, sit down...
We've finally found a compatible   ribosome match for the Romulan.   But only one. You.
That is impossible. I am a   Klingon.

Different species, yes. But   Humans, Romulans, Vulcans,   Klingons, Betazoids -- we're all   genetically similar. We have   comparable cell structures. And   you have what this Romulan   needs. There's absolutely no   risk to you...
You did understand that was the   purpose of all the testing...
I have no objection to tests.
You have an objection to being   a donor.
Yes.
Lieutenant, I understand your   feelings about the Romulans.   But this is not the time or   place...
If you had seen them kill your   parents, you would understand,   Doctor. It is always the time   and place for those feelings.
This Romulan did not kill your   parents. And you are the only   one who can save his life.
Then he will die.
I don't need him to like the idea,   Captain... just to do it.
There is no alternative?
The alternative is the Romulan   will die. Worf is quite correct   on that point.
We need him alive...       It is easy to forget that our   Lieutenant Worf is not human.   His values are very different from   yours and mine.
Of course they are. But he is   also an officer of Starfleet...   and this is...
... this is a personal matter...
It's very personal, Captain.   Especially to the Romulan who's   dying in my Sickbay. Maybe he   has a family waiting for him to   come home.
Worf is a good man. I know with   a word of encouragement from you   he will do the right thing.
Order him.
Encourage him.
A captain's encouragement is   difficult to refuse, Doctor.       And difficult to offer to a man   whose feelings run so deep.
Even if it means the life of the   Romulan?
I must respect his personal   views... even if I do not share   them. He will have to live with   the consequences of his decision.
We will all have to.
I wish you'd put that away.
You're afraid of dying.
You bet I am. Who isn't?
I'm not.
Right.
To die in the service of my   people...
Ah, the Romulan path to glory.
You can be sarcastic -- now. But   in a few millennia, when humans   are extinct and the Romulan Empire   spans the galaxy...
You really believe that stuff,   don't you, Commodore?
Our culture is far older and wiser   than yours. It's inevitable that   we will prevail.
Well, if you're that sure of   yourselves, why be so   tight-lipped? You won't even tell   me your name.
I see no need to tell you.
Why? Is it a military secret or   something? I've told you mine.       Okay, Commodore... whatever you   say.
You may address me as Centurion   Bochra.
Ahh. Bochra. Good, solid Romulan   name. And you're a centurion.   Well, stay with it, you'll be a   commodore someday.
I'm not certain of the equivalent   Federation rank... but I do know   it's higher than lieutenant   commander.
What's the matter?
Nothing.
Wrong. Your heart rate just shot   way up.
It translates a wide range of   radiation into neural impulses.   Allows me to see.
Without it, you are blind?
Yes...
How did this happen?
I was born that way.
(honestly doesn't     understand)   And your parents let you live?
What kind of question is that?   Of course they let me live.
No wonder your race is weak. You   waste time and resources on   defective children...
Defective? Listen, Commodore --   I'm a chief engineer in Starfleet.   You don't get there by being   defective.
But if you can't see...
I can see things you can't even   imagine.
Whoa...
I'm having some sort of polarity   shift. The diagnostic insists   everything's fine...
Your body temperature's gone up   another full degree...
What are you saying?
It's this place... All that   electromagnetic soup is playing   hell with our nervous systems.   Your metabolism's messed up...   so's my interface with the VISOR.
We've got to get out of here   while we still can.
Sit down.
Bochra...
Sit down.
What's that?
Just a background fluctuation,   Commander... he hasn't found it   yet.
Then he must be hurt... or dead.       How long before another window,   Data?
There are none indicated,   Commander. I have no way to   predict.
Incoming Romulan transmission,   Captain.
They're early.
The Romulan warbird should still   be twenty-nine minutes away from   the edge of the Neutral Zone.
Close enough, however, to see   we're not there.       On screen.
Picard, I'm approaching the   Federation border and the   Enterprise is not to be found.   Why?
My away team has not been able   to leave the surface because of   the storms.
And my officer?
He is alive.
His life remains in jeopardy?
Yes.
And yet you will still not permit   me to cross into your precious   Federation space to retrieve   him...
If the point hasn't been made   clearly, Commander, let me make   it again.
Romulan warships do not enter   Federation space unless they are   prepared to do battle.
But a mission of mercy...
A mission to recover one of your   officers who was caught on a   Federation planet. For reasons   still unknown...
I have already explained that.
And I have rejected your   explanation.
Territories... you would measure   territories against a man's life?
Commander, your singular concern   for a life is impressive. Do   not risk any more lives by leaving   the Neutral Zone. Picard out.
Bochra, you're in bad shape.
My vision's getting worse.   There's a beacon out there...   it'll get us back to my ship...   but not if I can't find it.
I can't surrender to the   Federation.
Then stay here and die.
If the situation were reversed...   would you not die to avoid   capture?
I don't know. I might... if I   thought it was necessary. If the   stakes were high enough.       But they'd have to be pretty damn   high.
Guess I'd make a pretty lousy   Romulan, huh... ?
I no more wish to die than you   do.
You mean Romulans aren't always   ready to sacrifice themselves on   command?
No more than humans are frail,   weak-willed children without any   conception of loyalty or duty.
Bochra -- there are times when   dying for one's ideals is   necessary.       Do you believe this is one of   those times?
Let's find that beacon.
What is it?
Everything's gone blank.       I'm blind.
Come.
You are busy. Forgive my   intrusion.
For what it's worth, I understand   your bitterness.
With respect, sir... you cannot.       I am asked to give up the very   lifeblood of my mother, of my   father, to those who murdered   them.
Must you blame all Romulans for   that?
Yes.
Forever, Worf?       What if the Federation should make   peace with the Romulans someday...
Impossible.
Not long ago, your people said   the same thing about humans.

And so many on both sides died   in that war. How could you and   I be here now... like this...   if we were unable to let go of   the anger, the blame.       When does it end, Worf? If the   Romulan dies, does his family   carry the bitterness forward   another generation?
Then you believe I should.
What I believe doesn't matter.
My Starfleet training tells me   one thing. Everything I am tells   me another.
Lieutenant Worf, report to   Sickbay.
Acknowledged.
Lieutenant, his life is coming   to an end. I thought it important   for you to see him again.
It is not too late to change your   mind.
Come close to me, Klingon. Let   me die with my hands at your   throat.
I am the only one who can keep   you alive.
You?
There is a substance within my   cells which you need to survive...
You have come to hear me beg for   my life.
No.
I would rather die than pollute   my body with Klingon filth.
I have lost almost all feeling   in my legs.
My synapses must be turning to   jelly. The VISOR's fine, but I   can't see a thing.
How do we locate the beacon?
We don't.
Do all humans give up so easily?
Are all Romulans so pushy?   Bochra, we're lost... unless   you've got something that can   smell neutrinos.
We have the sensor device you were   carrying.
My tricorder? It isn't set up   to detect neutrinos.
But your eye device does. Connect   them.

That's crazy. They don't speak   the same language. I'd never get   an accurate sampling...    (stops; maybe it's not     so crazy)   But, then, I don't need an   accurate sampling. I just need   a pointer... a neutrino Geiger   counter.
Still not possible.
You cannot do it?
Under normal circumstances, maybe.   Here, no way.
Why?
Because I can't see. Adapting   the neural output pods of the   VISOR is tricky work. It can't   be done by "touch."
Then I'll be your eyes.
The storm is beginning to subside,   Captain... we should have a   window in less than an hour...
Still no indication he's found   the beacon, sir...
Assemble an away team...
Yes, sir...
Captain... the Romulan warship   has crossed the Neutral Zone   border. It is in Federation space   and heading toward us.
Stand by, Number One.       Red Alert.
... make sure the scan select   limiter matches the VISOR output   range.
Not so fast...
Done.
Now close the case and place the   neural output pods in contact   with the tricorder scanner heads.
Ready.
Let her rip.
Bearing three-five-zero.
We did it! The first   Federation-Romulan co-venture.
The storm may be breaking.
With any luck an electromagnetic   window will be opening up and we   can get out of here.
At which point I'll be your   prisoner.
Can you walk?
I don't know...
Straight ahead...
You wished to see me, Captain.
Yes, Lieutenant.       I assume you know what this is   about...

The Romulan ship will reach us   within the hour, Lieutenant. If   our patient dies... it may be   just the excuse the Romulan   commander needs to start an   incident. The death of a Romulan   officer at the hands of the   Federation! Think of it.
I have, Captain.
There is no question that this   Romulan is more valuable to us   alive than dead, Lieutenant.
I understand.

Sometimes the moral obligations   of command are less than clear.   I weigh the good of the many   against the needs of the   individual... and try to balance   them as realistically as possible.   God knows I don't always succeed.
I have not had cause to complain,   Captain.
You wouldn't complain even if you   had cause, Lieutenant.
If you order me to agree to the   transfusion, I will, of course,   obey.
I cannot order you. I will not   order you, Lieutenant. But I ask   you. I beg you to volunteer.
I cannot, Captain.
Lieutenant...
Sir?
Dismissed.
Picard to Doctor Crusher.
Go ahead.
Do not continue to enlist   Lieutenant Worf's assistance.
I won't have to, Captain. The   Romulan has died.
We've found it.
Now we have to change its signal   pattern so the Enterprise knows   we've found it.
Will that be difficult?
Not with your help.
Scanners show a window, Captain.
Estimated duration?
Nine minutes, forty seconds.
No change in the neutrino beacon   signal, sir.
Romulan ship approaching. Bearing   three-fifty-four mark   two-eight-seven.
On screen.
Romulan is entering phaser range.
We are being hailed, sir.
On screen.
You have one chance to escape   destruction, Picard. Return my   officer at once.
You have entered Federation space   despite my warning, Commander.
You forced this situation. I will   not leave without him.
He is dead.
Then he is but the first to fall,   Picard.
The Romulan ship is routing power   to its forward disruptor array.
All shields to maximum.
Aye, sir.
Lock phasers on target.
Phasers locked and ready.
Captain -- the signal pattern from   the neutrino beacon is modulating.
Geordi!
We can't transport him with our   shields up.
If we lower our shields, the   Romulan will strike.
The electromagnetic window on the   planet is closing. Three minutes   remain.
Transporter Room. Lock onto the   coordinates of the neutrino beacon   and stand by.
Standing by, Captain.
Captain, the window is allowing   intermittant sensor readings...   There are still numerous ghost   images, but I believe we are   picking up two life forms near   the beacon...
Another Romulan?
I cannot say. The electromagnetic   interference prevents an accurate   reading.
But it is a likely hypothesis,   Number One. If Mister La Forge   located a second survivor...       Hail the Romulan ship, Lieutenant.
Aye, sir.       They're ignoring our hail, sir.
Repeat the hail -- all channels.       He has no way of knowing how   accurate our sensors are... put   on your poker face, Number One...       Open frequency.
Commander Tomalak. It would   appear our away team has rescued   a second man from your one man   ship.
They are on the surface, ready   to beam up. We are preparing   to do so.       After which we will return the   survivor to you.
No acknowledgement, Captain.

Commander, both our ships are   ready to fight. We have two   supremely powerful, destructive   arsenals at our command. Our next   actions will have serious   repercussions for both sides.       We have good reason to mistrust   one another, Commander, but we   have better reasons to set our   differences aside. The question,   of course, is who will show   vulnerability first.       The answer is -- I will. I must   lower my shields to transport   these men off the planet surface.

Once the shields are down, you   will have an opportunity to open   fire. If you do, you will not   only destroy the Enterprise and   its crew -- but also the   cease-fire that the Romulans and   the Federation now enjoy.
Lieutenant, lower the shields.   Leave hailing frequencies open.
Yes, sir.
Mister O'Brien. Transport Mister   La Forge and the Romulan directly   to the bridge.
Aye, sir. Energizing.
Security team to bridge.
Belay that order, Lieutenant.   Shields up.       No one is going to harm you.
You have my word.
Well, Commander?
If he has been in any way   mistreated...
I have given them no information,   Commander -- but I have not been   mistreated.       In fact, this human saved my life.
Commander, how is it possible you   didn't know of this second   Romulan on Galorndon Core?
A simple misunderstanding, Captain   Picard. I was obviously   misinformed as to the size of the   craft. I assure you, I intended   no deception.
Of course not.
You doubt my good faith?
Let's just say my faith would be   strengthened with a gesture --   such as powering down your   disruptors.
Disruptors powering down, Captain.
Thank you. Cancel Red Alert,   Lieutenant.
We will return your officer and   escort your ship back to the   Neutral Zone, Commander.
That is acceptable.
Mister La Forge, it's good to have   you back.
I have Centurion Bochra to thank,   sir.
Your vision is returning...
Yeah, gradually. Your heart   rate's slowing down.
Mister La Forge, Mister Worf --   escort our guest to Transporter   Room One.
Aye, sir.
Close call.
Too close, Number One.   Brinksmanship is a dangerous   game...
It was not in my power to save   him.
He was a loyal officer.
Lieutenant Commander La Forge.
Centurion Bochra.
You're not what I expected of a   Federation officer.
That's okay; you're not what I   expected of a Romulan, either.       That's a compliment.
That's the way to fight all the   wars from now on. Two guys on   a planet with no one else to talk   to and nowhere to go. Things get   settled in a hurry.
I'm gonna sleep for four days...
